A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name MRS. MARION ANDERSON

2. Your address 24 E. E. E. RAPTS., W. 13TH, VANCOUVER, B.C.

3. Date July 27, 1946

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country).
   TIVERTON, BRUCE COUNTY, ONTARIO.

5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   NEIL GEORGE MCCALLUM,
   Farmer, Implement Agent, Homestead Inspector, Land Agent.

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year).
   A spring month, 1882 or 1883 - not sure which.

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   NEWDALE & MINNEDOSA, MANITOBA - 1877 to 1878-83
   MOOSOMINX - I lived a few months in FTGARRY and HEADINGLY on arrival from ONTARIO.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc).
   I was a small child about 4 years of age.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   My parents wanted to build up a home of their own in the newly opening up Western Canada, took me along.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?).
    Agents were going into Ontario when the Canadian Pacific Railway was being built through what was later called Saskatchewan. They were telling of the homesteads of land to be for just $10 each and the work they put on it. This was an attractive appeal to young people who wanted to get away on their own. It far off fields where there was more room. I understood better when after 20 years I went with my mother back to Bruce and saw such big houses full of people on such small farms. I think it was 100 acres each. It seemed strange to me going from the wide open prairie where houses were small and far apart.

1. Your full name: MRS. MARION ANDERSON

3. Date: [illegible]

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): NEIL GEORGE MCALLUM, BRUCE COUNTY, ONTARIO.

5. What was your father's name and occupation?

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): A spring month, 1872 or 1873.

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:

NEWDALE & MINNEWAHA, MANITOBA - 1876-1878

MOOSOMILK HEADINGS, NEWBRUNSWICK, CANADA - 1878-1880

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not). You may use "I" was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.)

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

My parents wanted to build up a home of their own in the newly opening up western Canada. They thought it would be a good opportunity for them to start a new life.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

Agents were going into Ontario when the Canadian Pacific Railway was being built through what was later called Saskatchewan. They were telling of the homesteads of land in the west and each and the work they put on it. They also advertised appeals to young people who wanted to get away on their own to far off fields when after 20 years I went with my mother back to Buc and saw such a horrible fall of people on each small farm. I think it was 100 acres each. It seemed strange to me growing from the wide open prairie where horses were small as a post.
I had a telephone call this morning from Mr. Anderson, the principal of Wetmore school, and he wanted to give me some information regarding his mother. She is Mrs. Marian Anderson, 24 Exeter Apartments, 1540 West 15th Avenue, Vancouver 9, B.C. She was an early Saskatchewan teacher and took her training in Moosomin. She holds teacher training certificate number 1 (issued by someone prior to the formation of this province), has done some historical work on Moosomin and district. She is now 82 years of age.

Mr. Anderson advises me that his mother has answered some of your questionnaires. Quite obviously you must have been in contact with her, but he does not believe you were aware that she is the bearer of the first teacher training certificate.

Fred McGuinness

GOVERNMENT OF THE PROVINCE OF SASKATCHEWAN
DEPARTMENT MEMO
DATE September 15, 1954

FROM Fred McCallumness
TO Dr. Lewis Thomas

RE:

Anderson, the principal of Wetmore school, and he wanted to give me some information regarding his mother. She is Mrs. Marian Anderson, 24 Exeter Apartments, 1540 West 15th Avenue, Vancouver, B.C. She was an early Saskatchewan teacher and took her training in Moosomin. She holds teacher training certificate number 1 (issued by someone prior to the formation of this province), has done some historical work on Moosomin and district. She is now 82 years of age.

Mr. Anderson advises me that his mother has answered some of your questionnaires. Quite obviously you must have been in contact with her, but he does not believe you were aware that she is the bearer of the first teacher training certificate.

Fred McCallumness
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Old people thought their children were going too far away, facing dangers—Indians, wild animals, cold, blizzards, lack of drinking water & comforts of many kinds, no church or schools, no hospital, no doctor, no nurse.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

I came with my parents & baby sisters. It seems to me there were other friends coming from Bruce at the same time. In Brother's letters 1877 she speaks of others travelling with—

13. What means of transportation did you use?

We came by boat either from Port Elgin or Port Huron to Ft Garry, by ox cart and covered wagon (Bain) to Newdale. I can't remember how we got across to Moosomin.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

My little sister's shoe got out from under the tent one night & in the morning it was found all chewed up by some animal, and was unfit to wear. We didn't have many shoes after that while on the homestead at Newdale; we went barefoot in the summer & had moccasins in the winter. I think we did have shoes for Sunday—but had to take good care of them. Church service would be held in a Settler's home when Jas Robertson, Superintendent of missions would come then. We had to be ready with catechism & Bible verses.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

At Moosomin, North West Territory.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

I was settled longest in Sintaluta, where we had a General Store also a farm south near the Indian Reserve.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Sintaluta 1901-1933

Regina 1933-1953

We didn't live on the farm but Mr Anderson liked going out there & found it useful to put cattle, horses, pigs etc., he would get from customers who would pay in that way for goods bought from our store.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

I didn't earn my living in Ontario, or after coming to Western Canada, unless it was by helping at home, washing dishes, sweeping, churning, etc., minding the baby (we had a cradle & a big rocking chair). My first earning of money was when I helped Mrs J.K. McInnis teaching the primary children in Public School. Later taught in Summer Schools and Fleming 5 years in yearly schools.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Old people thought this children were going too far away.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other group)? If so, how many people were in your party?

I came with my parents and siblings.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

We came by boat either from Portage la Prairie or Port Nelson.

14. How did you get to your destination?

We traveled by train to Winnipeg.

15. Where did you settle when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

We settled in Prince Albert.

16. What was the first thing you did after arriving in Saskatchewan?

We set up camp and started building our home.

17. What was the hardest part of settling in Saskatchewan?

The lack of resources and the harsh weather conditions.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada?

I worked as a laborer on a farm.

19. What was the most difficult aspect of living in Western Canada?

The isolation and the lack of amenities.

20. How did you adapt to life in Western Canada?

I learned to be independent and resourceful.

21. What was the biggest challenge you faced in Western Canada?

The harsh winters and the lack of jobs.

22. How did you overcome these challenges?

I worked hard and saved money to buy land.

23. What was the most rewarding aspect of living in Western Canada?

The opportunity to build a better future for my family.

24. How did you contribute to the community?

I helped build schools and churches.

25. What was the most memorable experience you had in Western Canada?

Meeting new people and making friends.

19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
I didn't write to relatives in Bruce Hill, but I had come back there with another woman. After two years, I have a letter from Phoebe Boyd, written in 1885. I must have been writing to her. There are a few men from Moosomin and Fleming.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
David Russell Anderson was my husband. We were married in 1901 in Yorkton, Assa.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?
My father was a great booster for Saskatchewan. He was the means of some of his friends settling in the Mennonite district. Early settlers were setting out accounts being far from the market. He advised ones intending to come to farm that the R.R. was soon coming. There were some who came by train at first.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.
We, as a family, camasabo to Saskatchewan at the same time and lived together till one brother married a girl child of Moosomin & came to Nelson. We B.C. to live. I came to Alberta to live, too late, which was old enough, there as a family 32 years. We had paying jobs in and around Moosomin.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
Sometime in the 80s one fell on the homestead at Newdale. We were eating dinner at a long table. Someone spoke. Suddenly someone jumped up and tried to jump into the fireplace. All adults jumped up and grabbed sashes which were always on hand for an occasion. They rushed out to fight. Mother told me to look like this & rushed out to fight. Mother told me to look like this & rushed out to fight. Mother told me to look like this & rushed out to fight. Mother told me to look like this & rushed out to fight. Mother told me to look like this & rushed out to fight. Mother told me to look like this & rushed out to fight. Fire hurt & through a stubble field; all was given up for fire guard against another stubble fire. The fire died. That Prayes saved the day.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
Not much. At Newdale, we usually walked. I would be tired out trying to keep up to mother when she would take me with her to visit a neighbor, but I didn't grumble for fear she wouldn't take me again. Sunday School was held in the granary. Sometimes there was church service in the same building. We had to go to town earlier than the service. After harvest, Father would take a load of wheat to the mill at Minnedosa, which was so miles away. He would be 3 days away & would have flour, bran & shortcake with him. There would always be candy put in for us, too.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

I didn't write to relatives or friends in my old home.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife and place of marriage.

David Russell Anderson was my husband.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, where did they settle?

My family came from Ontario to Saskatchewan.

22. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

Sure, we were eating dinner at a long table when a machine came down. Suddenly someone yelled "The smoke of a Prairie fire coming towards us!" and the wind being in that direction, all adults jumped up and walked outside, which was always our habit for an occasion like this. We were always prepared for an occasion like this. We were always prepared for an occasion like this.

23. How much did you travel about in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often?

Not much at first, but we usually walked when the weather was nice. We would take a ride in the spring and fall, but not in the winter.

24. What was school like in your area?

School was held in our church building in the spring and fall, but not in the winter.

25. What was life like in the community?

Life was hard, but we were happy with what we had.

25. When was the first car used in the community?
   G.K. Grass Sintaluta & Herb Hall Wolseley had the first
   I remember of about 1915.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   A Ford Studebaker made a big noise & took lots of gas.
   It was his brothers at Watson's & Anderson bought it in order to help
   the poor farmers who needed it.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Suddenly, in Moosomin good stores were found.
   R.D. McNaughton's first department store; I have a
   picture of the staff.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns
    appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   Yes, there and all the smaller stores.

29. How often did you shop in the early days? It seems to me we went
    daily for groceries, school books or material to sew—that is
    when we were in Moosomin.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town reg-
    ularly on Saturdays?
    In Sintaluta all the time for 30 years, people from the
    Red Top districts would come to town Saturdays & Co.
    Father around, many of them till late at night keeping the store
    open up to all hours till they would take their purchases
    away.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?
    What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction
    of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion
    of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
    I never bought regularly from Eaton's, but would
    buy for things we could get at home, or could get
    much cheaper by sending away. R.D. McNaughton's
    Departmental Store carried most everything we
    needed when we lived in Moosomin 1883-1900.
    My first fur coat, a form-fitting astrakhan short
    one, a wedge-shaped fur cap & gloves were
    bought there, with money earned from teaching.
    Many people got that they would come to our
    store and have goods charged & send their money
    away to Toronto. Some of these bills were never
    paid. It was well for all concerned when it was "cash"
    shipped before they could take the goods out. Some women
    at Anderson

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
    We had one in the store Sintaluta before 1914.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying
    permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did
    you make this decision?
    It was with the idea of staying. We were a family
    of girls. Father would have no help from boys or
    the farm & he thought he would give us the best
    schooling available, so decided with mother to make
    their home in Moosomin town and learn some-
    thing whereby we could make a living for our-
    selves.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

1885: Neil McCallum elected to 1st School Board, Moosemin. He was active in affairs of Education and Church. Also sport and Lodge work. He was an Oddfellow also Rebecca.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

Years after, Rev Dan McLauchlin, from the pulpit in St Paul's church Nelson B.C. gave tribute to mother by saying that the lady who had given him his first instruction in Sunday school, was present that day in the congregation she had invited the children around to meet at her home every Sabbath. There was no regular church service. This was at Newdale Manitoba on the homestead in the early 80's.

39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

I have the diary written by mother, in pencil as she travelled from Headingley Manitoba by covered wagon to Newdale Manitoba. It's hard to describe.

Also I've been saving clippings for years in scrapbooks. A few photographs are left from ones which have been given away. We hear that Curling pictures sent to the Regina Club have likely been destroyed by vandals. If there is anything of any use I'll send them back.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

Mail would come to the Post Office, perhaps once a week and we would go for it, in some neighbor's house. Later a mail man would come & hand in your mail or put it in your box outside the door. In the City, the mail comes once a day; it used to be twice, and letters put through the door or left in a holder at front doors (in an apt.)

Miss Vivian Stevenson

Maureen Gaye Anderson, daughter of Harvie & Dorothy,
my only grandchild, 12 years old, 16th of July and
was here in Vancouver for her birthday with her
parents, from Regina, Saskatchewan.

The stage coach in the 90's did a good business
carrying passengers as well as mail.
I have travelled by one once from Moosomin to Birtle Man.
Another time,
I was on the stage coming from Fish Lake, Moore Mt.
The manager of the hotel was the driver. I had to return
before the rest at camp as my holiday of 2 weeks, from
my summer school was up. Mr. Smith A.H., & his wife
arranged for this outing. He was High School teacher and
invited students who wished & would subscribe to rules
to attend. Horse teams or democrats took us there. Others

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Old friends and relatives didn't favor the idea of young families moving to such a far-away land, but didn't try to stop them going.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

I travelled with my family, also friends of my parents, with the idea of looking for land and new homes.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Started from Port Colborne and came down the Lake Erie Canal, then by covered wagon drawn by a team of oxen. Hugh is going ahead with the cart, one or two behind him was hired to take the stuff out. We had four cart loads, 4,000 pounds weight, for which he gets $50 per load. There were two cows, two hens & some pigs along. This is written from notes written in pencil, as she sat on the ground of the tent, by the light of the lantern.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

"Hugh, a young man from Bruce was travelling with us. Father was on ahead to Newdale & had the walls of a log house up."

We started from Headingly, Manitoba, in February about 1877. Mother wrote in her diary (which I have) of camping at Bay St Paul, 62 miles was as much as the oxen could go in a short day.

Next day Saturday - went 25 miles - cows about played out.

Sunday glad to rest at Portage La Prairie. Poplar Point on Monday, a most beautiful country well inhabited, hundreds of steers in view all the time. Saw droves of cattle coming in from the United States. Many neighbors & families from Bruce were travelling along too."

Moosomin N.W.T. I think it was the C.P.R. entering this part of the country, attracted father to move here.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? In Sintalula I lived from 1901 till 1933. We had a store in town.

Regina since 1933.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

Relatives and friends came from Bruce and settled in the Manor District upon the recommendation of my father. He predicted that the railway was going in there soon, and it did. The people have done well there on their farms.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

My parents and two sisters came west 1876. We lived longest together in Moosomin Assa. One sister married to a J. Dill Moosomin and went to Nelson B.C. to live. Mother and Father spent a number of years at Yorkton N.W.T. and their last years at Nelson B.C.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

June 1897 our Fleming School and all surrounding schools joined with Moosomin in celebrating the 60th anniversary of the reign of Queen Victoria. Each teacher was given a badge, given beforehand, was to head his or her own pupils and look after them in the Grand Parade made around the town and on to the grand stand, where choirs were sung by the schools & speeches made by prominent citizens. Governor General Dewdney and Party were present.

In 1900 at Yorkton a gramophone record was made of Mrs. Wallace's voice as she read a Psalm. Her husband wanted this, as she was ill & not expected to be better. A quartet from the choir sang "Unto the hills around do look up." I played the organ for them.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Mostly by foot in the earliest days as I remember. At Newdale (our first homestead) as soon as there was wheat oats & wagon father would go with a great to the mill at Moosehead (not sure). Once I went by stage from Fish Lake to Moosomin (about 45 miles). Another time I went by stage Mr. Green driving to Brittle partway on a trip to Yorkton.

When teaching at the summer schools, most of any rides were with people where I boarded. At my first school we went to the Fair at Lapella from Ravine Bank in a wagon drawn by young oxen. Had a ride back in a top buggy. At Fleming I had a Remington Bicycle to get around with. I could get home faster to Moosomin, for 9 miles away.

The Canadian Pacific Railway daily through Fleming. Horses in buggies, buckboards & democrats common.

At first it would be horses put in livery stables for some hours, while farmers & families shopped & visited & visited & visited.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

From open uncultivated Prairie, most homesteads and preemptions have been settled on, and made use of, principally in grain growing. Methods of farming have changed from the hand plow, seeder, binder etc. to disks combined etc. Frame, brick and stone houses for sod and log ones. Electrically lighted houses instead of coal oil lamps. The Canadian Pacific Railway through from coast to coast. Telephones, planes, motor cars in common use. Schools, churches & public buildings are available & near full now. Labor-saving devices too numerous to mention.

At Brandon Fair about 1896 Ella Ross (another teacher) and I attended the Brandon Fair for a day. We had to go the night before on the train. We didn't know anybody going there or there. It was considered a bold adventure. The price was 50 cents for anything we went to see. One thing was a gramophone on the street. A man handed me a phonograph.
